docs.lead_paragraph: That teenagers are often so sleep-deprived they can barely crawl out of bed in the morning is not news. But researchers have found that these days, even many babies no longer sleep like a baby. Infants average almost 90 minutes less sleep a day than the 14-hour minimum doctors recommend, according to a survey of more than 1,400 parents and others who care for children 10 and younger. The results are being released today.

headline.main: Poll Finds Even Babies Don't Get Enough Rest

docs.abstract: National Sleep Foundation study finds that even babies do not get enough sleep; holds that infants average almost 90 minutes less sleep per day than suggested 14-hour minimum; 52 percent of parents report that pediatricians do not ask about sleep habits; study suggests that hectic life style of today's parents may contribute to lack of sleep for infants (M)
docs.snippet: That teenagers are often so sleep-deprived they can barely crawl out of bed in the morning is not news. But researchers have found that these days, even many babies no longer sleep like a baby.    Infants average almost 90 minutes less sleep a day...

docs.lead_paragraph: Emergency room doctors generally focus on immediate problems, not broader health care. But a new study suggests that as a result, they may often miss opportunities to head off major health problems down the road. After reviewing records for patients who visited four city emergency rooms over a one-week period, researchers from the Temple University Hospital and School of Medicine in Philadelphia found that many of the patients had signs of high blood pressure. More than 1,400 patients had elevated pressure of 140/90 or higher and 30 percent of them had severe hypertension. Most did not know it, the researchers said.
docs.abstract: Dr David J Karras, working with Temple University Hospital and School of Medicine in Philadelphia, prepares study of emergency room care; finds that while emergency room workers focus on immediate health concerns they often overlook imminent health problems that may come up in future; suggests emergency care doctors should refer patients for further treatment when they discover underlying health problems (S)
docs.snippet: Emergency room doctors generally focus on immediate problems, not broader health care. But a new study suggests that as a result, they may often miss opportunities to head off major health problems down the road.    After reviewing records for...

docs.lead_paragraph: If sexually active young women are given ready access to emergency contraception, will they be more likely to have unprotected sex? Apparently not, reports a study appearing this week in The Journal of Pediatric and Adolescent Gynecology.
docs.abstract: Dr Melanie A Gold, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine researcher, leads study that finds women who possess morning after birth control pillsare not more likely to have unprotected sex; study, published in Journal of Pediatric and Adolescent Gynecology, shows that having morning after pills at home does increase likelihood of women using them in case of unprotected sex (S)
docs.snippet: If sexually active young women are given ready access to emergency contraception, will they be more likely to have unprotected sex?    Apparently not, reports a study appearing this week in The Journal of Pediatric and Adolescent Gynecology.

docs.lead_paragraph: After the federal advisory issued last week, the most popular antidepressant drugs may soon carry boldface warnings that patients who take them may become suicidal in the first weeks of therapy. Although the science behind the move is murky, the effects of the warning may be beneficial.

headline.main: Learning From Prozac: Will New Warning Shift Old Views?

docs.abstract: Tanya Luhrmann, University of Chicago professor and author of Of Two Minds: An Anthropologist Looks at Modern Psychiatry, discusses move by Food and Drug Administration to have warnings about possible suicidal reaction by patient's begining antidepressant drugs put on medications; stresses that there is not yet evidence of clear link between increased suicides and starting antidepressant routine, but sees advantages to warning; suggests that doctors will likely be more active with patients and encourage regular visits and psychotheraphy along with drugs; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: After the federal advisory issued last week, the most popular antidepressant drugs may soon carry boldface warnings that patients who take them may become suicidal in the first weeks of therapy.    Although the science behind the move is murky, the...

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: TWO MINDS: AN ANTHROPOLOGIST LOOKS AT MODERN PSYCHIATRY (BOOK)

docs.lead_paragraph: A popular cream that eases the symptoms of menopause exposes women to higher levels of the hormone progesterone than has been commonly thought, researchers have found. Pro-Gest, one of more than two dozen creams containing natural progesterone, is a widely used alternative to synthetic hormone therapies that have been linked to a higher risk of breast cancer and heart disease. Millions of tubes of progesterone cream are sold annually.

headline.main: Possible Peril Found in Menopause Cream

docs.abstract: Dr Anne Hermann conducts study at Bassett Healthcare, Cooperstown, NY, that shows women using Pro-Gest, progesterone cream, and women taking hormone pill Prometrium have same levels of hormone in blood stream; data, presented at American Society for Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics conference, suggest natural cream puts women at risk similar to that associated with hormone replacement therapy; Susan Cruzan, Food and Drug Administration spokeswoman, holds that more research needs to be completed on menopause creams and their risks (M)
docs.snippet: A popular cream that eases the symptoms of menopause exposes women to higher levels of the hormone progesterone than has been commonly thought, researchers have found.    Pro-Gest, one of more than two dozen creams containing natural progesterone, is...

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical texts describe chickenpox, or varicella, as a highly contagious but rather mild childhood disease that only rarely results in serious complications, a fact that has set off decades of controversy over whether the vaccine to prevent chickenpox is warranted. Had anyone asked me, I would have said absolutely. Although I had none of the characteristics associated with more severe cases, at age 8 I had what my pediatrician called the ''worst case of chickenpox'' he had ever seen -- more than 1,000 intensely itchy blisters all over my body.

headline.main: Avoid Chickenpox. (Oatmeal Bath Is No Picnic.)

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on chickenpox and recent studies that show immunity to illness through vaccination wears off over time; concern over when to administer vaccination to infants discussed; recognizing chickenpox and some basic ways to ease pain of blisters described; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Medical texts describe chickenpox, or varicella, as a highly contagious but rather mild childhood disease that only rarely results in serious complications, a fact that has set off decades of controversy over whether the vaccine to prevent chickenpox...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes when former smokers go out drinking, by the end of the evening they are hooked on cigarettes again. Why? Researchers say that in part, it may come down to simple brain chemistry. A new study has found that alcohol, even in very small amounts, appears to enhance the pleasurable effects of nicotine.

headline.main: Smoking, and a Link to Drink

docs.abstract: Dr Jed E Rose, Duke University Nicotine Research Program's lead author of recent study, finds that even small amounts of alcohol enhance pleasurable effects of nicotine; study helps explain why many former smokers light up while out having drinks with friends; research appears in Nicotine & Tobacco Research, journal; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Understanding Health Care,'' by Richard Saul Wurman. Top Publishing Group, $25. Billed as a ''visual guidebook,'' Mr. Wurman's work is a consumer's miscellany of information, covering ways the body functions and various ills that plague it.
docs.abstract: Richard Saul Wurman book Understanding Health Care is visual guidebook of wide range of medical information; stresses need for patients to be more aware of personal health; photo (S)
docs.snippet: ''Understanding Health Care,'' by Richard Saul Wurman. Top Publishing Group, $25.      Billed as a ''visual guidebook,'' Mr. Wurman's work is a consumer's miscellany of information, covering ways the body functions and various ills that plague it.

docs.lead_paragraph: If stereotypes are to be believed, one of the best ways to develop hypochondria is to enroll in medical school, and one of the best ways to recover is to graduate. Medical students are notorious hypochondriacs. So commonly do they scuttle into university health services with self-made diagnoses of terminal illness (usually the one they are reading about at the time) that the phrase ''medical student syndrome'' was coined several decades ago to describe their behavior.

headline.main: Doctors, Too, Have Fears; They Just Go Underground

docs.abstract: Medical students are often labeled hypochondriacs; working with and learning about variety of diseases seems to be root cause of condition; studies show that 70 to 80 percent of medical students have unfounded fear of disease during their school years (M)
docs.snippet: If stereotypes are to be believed, one of the best ways to develop hypochondria is to enroll in medical school, and one of the best ways to recover is to graduate.    Medical students are notorious hypochondriacs. So commonly do they scuttle into...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Quirky Kids,'' by Dr. Perri Klass and Dr. Eileen Costello. Ballantine, $23.95. In this book, Dr. Klass, a pediatrician and well-known author of fiction and nonfiction, and Dr. Costello, a primary care pediatrician in Boston, explore the world of children who fall ''outside the common patterns'' and offer help for parents, including those who just knew something was wrong, ''yet had their concerns dismissed by their pediatricians.''
docs.abstract: Drs Perri Klass and Eileen Costello book Quirky Kids stresses that all children are different and develop at their own pace and in own way; photo (S)
